document.title: Washington, DC K-12 Social Studies Standards Revised Standards

A5685E30B1D945FBB8418B2420A81A4B.description: Analyze the reasons for, and consequences of, choices individuals make when purchasing goods and services.

90695D18E9D3430E9BB6A29193AD7360.description:
Explain how wealth and scarcity affect individual and group power and the ability to make decisions about personal savings
and spending.

F070A968ACCA4B5685AF05816DC97FB8.description:
Describe the goods and services that communities need (e.g., grocery stores, transportation, public safety, etc.) and identify
how they are provided by local government and private businesses.

DE78AB389DEC4B0884546D0E5F2245D6.description:
Explain the varied ways that people labor, define the term income, and describe the kinds of work that people do inside and
outside of the home.

3734862CCC2E47FA87AE54853DCCED11.description:
Describe and locate different human, natural or capital resources in Washington, DC and compare the availability of those
resources across the city.

E60AB5489AC549F7956202B0034BE186.description:
In this driving concept, students will learn basic economic concepts and the various goods, resources and services that meet the
needs of Washingtonians through analyzing how individuals make choices in a free market economy. They will gain an initial
understanding of inequalities across the city by comparing the availability of human, natural, and capital resources.

D048463C93BA4D6482EB97DF13DBF1EB.description: Driving Concept 4: Meeting a Community's Needs

88DB20B529934F6EA137DAD7A9174584.description:
Compare different accounts of the same historical event in Washington, DC and propose possible reasons for the
differences.

663C5BEB034E41899216363BBD74A806.description:
Describe why some groups of people were treated unjustly in the past and identify actions individuals took to promote
greater equality and fairness in society.

04080609760B44A7B5B54E0F3E09BE05.description:
Analyze texts, family, or community stories, and/or historical photographs to compare family, school, and/or community life
in the past and the present.

B994865C9310491891C96FB8CF941896.description: Identify significant events in the history of the school community and explain what makes each event significant.

7A66C1BADC4F48CBB8EFA98B985E9E4F.description:
Analyze maps and images of the Chesapeake region and Washington, DC from different historical periods to describe the
ways the community has changed over time.

16F9F84F130B40039552A248835CF49B.description:
Differentiate between events that happened long ago and events that happened in the not-so-distant past and order the
events on a timeline.

30959C9F7C864A088CD33705D5969158.description:
Through this driving concept, students will analyze the ways Washington, DC has changed over time, using maps, images, and
storytelling about significant events and people in Washington, DC’s history. Students will compare life in the past to life in the
present to build an understanding of how and why people made changes to the city.

A3979D82B1F84D52A2EBE9864B57F127.description: Driving Concept 3: My Community Then and Now

4A0EA78AFCE143C1BEC1B6A4BB34D71A.description: Identify a problem caused by humans to the local environment and propose a solution.

3751D1A6AAD9487B9A431DA8707BED1E.description:
Describe how location, weather, and physical environment affect the way people live, including the effects on their food,
clothing, shelter, transportation, and recreation.

B90D467044F54368B23B8CA52E490F4D.description:
Describe how and why people have changed the physical landscape of the local community and/or the greater Washington,
DC area over time.

F134F1F8D65D48ACBA708B6388BD419C.description:
Construct a simple map of the classroom, school, or local community, using cardinal directions, physical features, and map
symbols.

7FA3AEADAD864389BAE8A09B7E97C285.description:
Describe the absolute and relative locations of Washington, DC area institutions, businesses, or landmarks, and describe the
physical characteristics of those places.

90E68A7C864D433C8A227A625AB1497F.description: Locate and explain physical features on maps (e.g., mountains, oceans, rivers, lakes, etc.).

FBF5FAEAB3694708A18E463D86FEADD1.description: Compare the features of a city, county, state, country, and continent.

953016F602EE4212B8EA19DBC9DC4FD5.description:
Identify the local neighborhood, Washington, DC, the United States, and North America on a map, and identify key political
features of the region.

3EB751E87BF14547A0F678C38EF83973.description: Analyze different representations of Washington, DC to make a claim about different places in the District.

2DB63E17C523412DBF2DA6CFF9A4280A.description:
In this driving concept, students analyze what makes their space in Washington, DC unique, using map skills and historical
sources to clarify how humans changed the landscape of the city over time. Students will evaluate and propose solutions for a
local environmental issue in the city.

A8C05CD0AC8F4DCEAD2D29ED3883F7B2.description:
Identify issues or needs in the school, local, or global community that students care about, and generate possible actions to
create positive change.

AE20EC976703413B8CA6A62041E2E7CA.description:
Identify a source of information about Washington, DC, and explain how the author’s job, training, and/ or experiences
effect the reliability of information.

C89DEAB1780C4456A3E891047EF2433D.description:
Describe how voting and elections can exemplify democratic principles, including but not limited to equality, freedom,
fairness, respect for individual rights, citizen participation, majority rules, and accepting the results of an election.

D0072FBABF6041C98FD30DFBA95D99CC.description: Describe how voting and elections determine who will be president, vice president, and mayor.

A1B667C09D7749618664E130E47EE6BE.description:
Identify community leaders from the past (e.g. George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, Susan B. Anthony, Harriet Tubman,
Dolores Huerta, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Harvey Milk, Wilma Pearl Mankiller, Lee Yick, and Liliʻuokalani) and compare how
each person created change.

DD4629E690B7418C95F700084F8C8BE9.description:
Identify symbols, songs, and phrases that unify the community of the United States and symbols and songs that unify
different communities within the United States, as well as national holidays that commemorate American history.

7AF10774448B4BA89A8E4AE095DAD7BA.description:
Identify and describe the roles and responsibilities of current leaders, including the president of the United States and the
mayor of Washington, DC.

114823DE2D5E4D1D94B997C71E8685E6.description: Describe the responsibilities of a leader, and identify characteristics of effective and just leaders.

DEB889FCE4DD494FB7D39672A80353FF.description:
Describe how different individuals and groups in a local or global community provide services, uphold rights, and work to
promote the common good for all members.

13240B4979804153817D163685453E14.description: Evaluate the rules and processes of the classroom, and identify characteristics of just and effective rules and laws.

3BD63146D9B54DCFB8FAF834FF4113CE.description:
Identify and define the rights of learners in the classroom community, and describe how individuals can work together to
respect the rights of community members.

82DE4D6A30BB436AAE8AB7F9AF615A59.description:
Describe ways in which groups of people in the same community can hold different beliefs and live their daily lives in
different ways, while still working together toward shared goals.

DFFF0DA95CC0450B984E4E9761AEF690.description:
Explain the ways in which different populations, including but not limited to, Latinx, Black, Asian, immigrant, religious, and
Indigenous communities, have shaped and defined the community of Washington, DC.

2C520BD1406042BEB1A04AFEC751607C.description:
Describe the ways individuals with different backgrounds, including ethnicity, gender, religion, sexual orientation, ability,
economic status, and beliefs are all part of the same community.

6C2C7AF0A66C42D0B1DC8C8D791DFD79.description: Explain what constitutes a community and describe characteristics of different communities.

4902FAA39A56487DA5C99F17DBB06A97.description:
In this driving concept, students will identify and compare different types of community (e.g., their neighborhood, city, and
nation) and the ways that they define leadership, decision-making, conflict resolution, and change-making. Students will
evaluate the various communities that they are a part of (classroom, neighborhood, and world) and analyze the characteristics of
a just, inclusive, and free society. Teachers should use read-aloud texts, images, songs, artifacts, and other materials that detail
the contributions of leaders and community members from the past and present.
